entry.title: 1049 Counting Ones (30åˆ†)
entry.content:
The task is simple: given any positive integer $N$, you are supposed to count the total number of 1â€™s in the decimal form of the integers from 1 to $N$. For example, given $N$ being 12, there are five 1â€™s in 1, 10, 11, and 12.

Input Specification

Each input file contains one test case which gives the positive $N$ ($\le 2^{30}$).

Output Specification

For each test case, print the number of 1â€™s in one line.

Sample Input

Sample Output

åˆ†æ

é¢˜ç›®å¤§æ„ä¸ºï¼šç»™å®šä¸€ä¸ªæ•°å­—$N$ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡ä»1åˆ°$N$ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰æ•°å­—é‡Œ1å‡ºç°çš„æ¬¡æ•°ã€‚

ä»¥æ•°å­—abcdefä¸ºä¾‹éå†æ¯ä¸€ä½ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡è¯¥ä½å–1æ—¶çš„æ•°å­—ä¸ªæ•°ï¼Œä»¥dä¸ºä¾‹

  • è‹¥$d=0$ï¼Œå·¦ä¾§å¯å–$[0,abc)$ï¼Œå³ä¾§å¯å–$[0, 99]$ï¼Œå…±$abc*10^2$ä¸ª
  • è‹¥$d>1$ï¼Œå·¦ä¾§å¯å–$[0, abc]$ï¼Œå³ä¾§å¯å–$[0, 99]$ï¼Œå…±$(abc+1)*10^2$ä¸ª
  • è‹¥$d=1$ï¼Œå·¦ä¾§å–$[0,abc)$æ—¶å³ä¾§å¯å–$[0, 99]$ï¼Œå·¦ä¾§å–$abc$æ—¶ï¼Œå³ä¾§å¯å–$[0, ef]$ï¼Œå…±$abc*10^2+ef+1$ä¸ª

å°†æ¯ä¸€ä½çš„ä¸ªæ•°æ±‚å’Œå³å¯å¾—åˆ°ç»“æœ

entry.title: 1003 Emergency (25åˆ†)
entry.content:
As an emergency rescue team leader of a city, you are given a special map of your country. The map shows several scattered cities connected by some roads. Amount of rescue teams in each city and the length of each road between any pair of cities are marked on the map. When there is an emergency call to you from some other city, your job is to lead your men to the place as quickly as possible, and at the mean time, call up as many hands on the way as possible.

Input Specification

Each input file contains one test case. For each test case, the first line contains 4 positive integers: $N (â‰¤500)$ - the number of cities (and the cities are numbered from $0$ to $Nâˆ’1$), $M$ - the number of roads, $C_1$ and $C_2$ - the cities that you are currently in and that you must save, respectively. The next line contains $N$ integers, where the $i$-th integer is the number of rescue teams in the $i$-th city. Then $M$ lines follow, each describes a road with three integers $c_1$, $c_â€‹2$ and $L$, which are the pair of cities connected by a road and the length of that road, respectively. It is guaranteed that there exists at least one path from $C_1$ to $C_2$.

Output Specification

For each test case, print in one line two numbers: the number of different shortest paths between $C_1$ and $C_2$, and the maximum amount of rescue teams you can possibly gather. All the numbers in a line must be separated by exactly one space, and there is no extra space allowed at the end of a line.

Sample Input

Sample Output

åˆ†æ

é¢˜ç›®å¤§æ„ä¸ºï¼šç°ç»™å®šä¸€å¼ æ— å‘å›¾ï¼ˆèŠ‚ç‚¹æœ‰æƒï¼‰ï¼Œæ±‚ä»ä¸€ç‚¹å‡ºå‘åˆ°å¦ä¸€ç‚¹çš„æœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„çš„æ¡æ•°ï¼Œä»¥åŠç»è¿‡èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æƒä¹‹å’Œçš„æœ€å¤§å€¼ã€‚

åˆ©ç”¨Dijkstraç®—æ³•ï¼Œæ±‚èµ·ç‚¹åˆ°å…¶ä½™ç‚¹çš„æœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„ã€‚ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰æ±‚æœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„æ¡æ•°ï¼šä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹åˆ†é…ä¸€ä¸ªnumè¡¨ç¤ºæœ€çŸ­è·¯å¾„æ¡æ•°ï¼Œåœ¨æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€è¿‘ç‚¹væ›´æ–°å…¶ä½™ç‚¹æ—¶ï¼Œè‹¥ä»¥æœ€è¿‘ç‚¹vä¸ºä¸­è½¬ç‚¹uä¸sè·ç¦»æ›´è¿‘åˆ™num[u]=num[v]ï¼›è‹¥è·ç¦»ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œåˆ™è¯´æ˜æœ‰å¤šæ¡è·¯å¾„ï¼Œå³num[u]+=num[v]ã€‚ï¼ˆ2ï¼‰æ±‚ç»è¿‡èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æƒä¹‹å’Œçš„æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼šä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹åˆ†é…ä¸€ä¸ªwè¡¨ç¤ºæƒé‡ä¹‹å’Œï¼ˆweightä¸ºè¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹æƒé‡ï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€è¿‘ç‚¹væ›´æ–°å…¶ä½™ç‚¹æ—¶ï¼Œè‹¥ä»¥æœ€è¿‘ç‚¹vä¸ºä¸­è½¬ç‚¹uä¸sè·ç¦»æ›´è¿‘ï¼Œåˆ™w[u]=weight[u]+w[v]ï¼›è‹¥è·ç¦»ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œåˆ™éœ€è¦åˆ¤æ–­å“ªæ¡è·¯å¾„æƒé‡ä¹‹å’Œæ›´å¤§ï¼Œw[u]=max(w[u],weight[u]+w[u])ã€‚

ACä»£ç

Amount of rescue teams in each city and the length of each road between any pair of cities are marked on the map. When there is an emergency call to you from some other city, your job is to lead your men to the place as quickly as possible, and at the mean time, call up as many hands on the way as possible.
